pr_title: [JENKINS-43889] Make sure Environments are always torn down (in AbstractBuild)

timeline.message:
[JENKINS-43889] Environment from pre-checkout SimpleBuildWrapper not always teared down

An Environment contributed by a pre-checkout SimpleBuildWrapper will not be teared
down is the build stops too early (for instance during SCM checkout).
Although JENKINS-43889 was not originally about SimpleBuildWrapper, but about a
"regular" BuildWrapper (in ssh-agent-plugin), it really is the same issue (with the
Environment being added by the preCheckout method).

[JENKINS-43889] AbstractBuildExecution: ensure Environments are always teared down

Before this change, in an AbstractBuildExecution, tearing down Environments used to
be left to the doRun() implementations.  But this comes too late to actually tear down
the ones which have been setup before checkout (by BuildWrapper#preCheckout, or
RunListener#setUpEnvironment).

Tearing down Environments is now done directly in AbstractBuildExecution#run(), in a
finally block.

The BuildExecution#doRun implementation is modified to take that into account.
But because in plugins (for instance maven-plugin) there are still implementations
of doRun() which could tear down Environments themselves, we use a dummy
Environment (TearDownCheckEnvironment) as a marker to check whether teardown
has been done already, and avoid doing it twice.
[JENKINS-43889] test tearDown is called only once (including for Maven builds)

timeline.author: res0nance

replies.bodyText: Actually, now I remember... It's not static because it is nested in a non-static nested class (AbstractBuild.AbstractBuildExecution). Do you think I should move it?
replies.author: thomasgl-orange

replies.bodyText: Would be better to avoid non-static nested classes when possible. Better safe than sorry
replies.author: oleg-nenashev

timeline.author: res0nance

timeline.bodyText: I'm not sure if this is the right approach since being interrupted usually means to exit ASAP
timeline.author: res0nance

replies.bodyText:
I don't have a set opinion on what to do after the tear-down loop in case we've caught an InterruptedException. I've chosen to Thread.currentThread().interrupt(), but maybe we could as well raise a new InterruptedException, or maybe simply set an appropriate build status.
But I really think that completing the iteration on remaining environments, even in case of an InterruptedException, is the right thing to do. Leaving temporary files behind, or orphan processes, by not tearing down the remaining environments seems "wrong" to me (when it can be avoided). I think of multiple build wrappers (environments) not as a list (although that's how it is implemented), but rather as nested try/finally blocks.
Let's wait for more reviews before changing this code...
replies.author: thomasgl-orange

replies.bodyText:
I don't have a set opinion on what to do after the tear-down loop in case we've caught an InterruptedException.

I've now changed my code to re-throw an InterruptionException. See #4517 (comment) and 625b783.

timeline.message: move environments tearing down to its own method

timeline.bodyText: For reviewers: This is the same as before
timeline.author: MRamonLeon

timeline.bodyText: From this line, all lines are the same
timeline.author: MRamonLeon

timeline.bodyText:
Does it make more sense to use here UNSTABLE? From its definition:
    /**
     * The build had some errors but they were not fatal.
     * For example, some tests failed.
     */
    public static final @Nonnull Result UNSTABLE = new Result("UNSTABLE",BallColor.YELLOW,1,true);

And if it was interrupted, what about ABORTED?
    /**
     * The build was manually aborted.
     *
     * If you are catching {@link InterruptedException} and interpreting it as {@link #ABORTED},
     * you should check {@link Executor#abortResult()} instead (starting 1.417.)
     */
    public static final @Nonnull Result ABORTED = new Result("ABORTED",BallColor.ABORTED,4,false);
timeline.author: MRamonLeon

replies.bodyText:
Regarding UNSTABLE on tearDown exception, I tend to agree, but it was FAILURE prior to this PR (in the BuildExecution#doRun implementation), so I don't really want to change this behavior here. It goes beyond the fix for "environments not always being torn down", and I don't know if some environments implementations rely on this behavior (throw exception, instead of returning false, to signal a fatal build error).
Regarding InterruptedException, after reading how it's handled in Run#execute(RunExecution) (and Executor#abortResult()), I've finally decided to re-throw an InterruptedException (the first one which has been caught) rather than calling Thread#interrupt(), and let it be handled by the caller (which will set an ABORTED result in the end, but with a few subtleties regarding the cause of interruption).
That's 625b783.
replies.author: thomasgl-orange

timeline.bodyText: Isn't it better to throw an interrupted exception here?
timeline.author: MRamonLeon

replies.bodyText: Yes, see my answer to your previous comment, and 625b783.
replies.author: thomasgl-orange

timeline.message: utility method to worsen a nullable Result
improve exceptions handling when tearing down environments

timeline.bodyText: This historical implementation just asks for concurrency issues at some point. Not blocking this change, because it does not make it any worse
timeline.author: oleg-nenashev

replies.author: thomasgl-orange

timeline.bodyText: InterruptedException in tearDownBuildEnvironments() will bypass this logic and cause loss of the original build result information. I doubt this is what we want
timeline.author: oleg-nenashev

replies.bodyText:
That's intentional, see #4517 (comment)
My understanding of how it works today is that an InterruptedException during an environment tearDown() would go up to Run#execute(RunExecution), where it is handled in a "special" way (Executor#abortResult()) to take user interruption cause into account. In the end, the result is ABORTED, effectively bypassing the result of the build steps.
I don't really want to change/rewrite that, it's not what this pull request is about. I've tried to change things "just enough" to make sure all environments are torn down even in this case (I'll still try to tear down remaining environments before re-throwing the exception), but no more than that.
I've added a test case (83c2602) which shows that:

the result is ABORTED in this case,
remaining environments are torn down.

Executing the same test without the rest of this pull-request still passes 1 (the ABORTED assertion), and fails on 2. (see thomasgl-orange/jenkins@dc71032 for a cherry pick of 83c2602 on top of master).
replies.author: thomasgl-orange
